Introduction

Nocturnal enuresis is defined as bed-wetting in children age â‰¥5.  The most common cause is delayed maturation of bladder control (ie, primary nocturnal enuresis), which occurs in an otherwise asymptomatic child who has never achieved prolonged nighttime dryness.  Less common, underlying medical conditions (eg, diabetes mellitus, urinary tract infection [UTI]) must be excluded based on a thorough history and evaluation.

Classification

Nocturnal enuresis is defined as bed-wetting in children age â‰¥5 and can be classified as primary or secondary (

):

  • Primary nocturnal enuresis (most common):  Defined as nighttime urinary incontinence in a child who has never achieved a prolonged period of nighttime dryness.  This condition affects approximately 15% of children age 5; males are twice as likely to be affected compared to females.  A family history of bed-wetting is the greatest risk factor.
  • Secondary nocturnal enuresis:  Characterized as new-onset bed-wetting after achieving urinary continence for â‰¥6 months.  This subtype is typically caused by an underlying medical condition (eg, UTI, diabetes mellitus) or psychosocial stressor (eg, bullying, birth of sibling).

Because a developing secondary condition may overlap with primary nocturnal enuresis, the absence of a prolonged period of nighttime dryness alone does not exclude an underlying medical condition as the cause of bed-wetting.

Pathogenesis

As neural pathways in the brain evolve over the first few years of life, voiding normally progresses from a primitive reflex to a purposeful action.  The process of developing bladder control involves the following (

figure 1
):

  • Awareness of bladder filling.
  • Suppression of bladder contractions by the cerebral cortex.
  • Coordination of sphincter/detrusor function in the pontine micturition center.

This process, and therefore toilet training, is typically complete by age 5 in most children.  However, a brain maturational delay in the development of bladder control may persist in school-aged children, resulting in primary nocturnal enuresis.  The pathogenesis related to exclusively nighttime symptoms may involve increased overnight urine output due to decreased antidiuretic hormone activity, excessive fluid consumption in the evenings, and/or reduced bladder capacity.

Clinical presentation

Primary nocturnal enuresis presents in children age â‰¥5 with discrete bed-wetting episodes and without a history of prolonged (â‰¥6 months) nighttime continence.

Patients do not have additional urinary symptoms (eg, frequency, urgency, hesitancy, pain) or daytime incontinence.

Differential diagnosis

Primary nocturnal enuresis is a diagnosis of exclusion and must be differentiated from underlying medical conditions that often (but not always) present after a child has achieved a prolonged period of nighttime continence.  These conditions are usually associated with additional urinary symptoms, systemic findings, or abnormalities on examination; an exception is psychologic stressors (eg, bullying, birth of a sibling) that may trigger isolated bed-wetting episodes.

Renal/urologic abnormalities

  • Urinary tract infection (UTI):  Enuresis can be the presenting symptom, but most patients also have dysuria, frequency, urgency, and/or suprapubic tenderness.  Leukocytes and/or nitrites on urinalysis are supportive of the diagnosis.
  • Bladder dysfunction:  Bladder dysfunction can be caused by an overactive bladder (abnormal bladder contraction), neurogenic conditions (eg, spina bifida), and anatomic/obstructive disorders (eg, posterior urethral valves [PUV] (
    figure 2
    )).  Although nocturnal enuresis can occur, patients typically have daytime incontinence as well and a history of recurrent UTIs; a weak urinary stream is also a common finding.  Examination may show cutaneous signs of spinal dysraphism in spina bifida (
    figure 3
    ), and urodynamic studies are typically abnormal.
  • Chronic kidney disease (CKD):  Acquired kidney injury, often from anatomic abnormalities in children (eg, PUV, vesicoureteral reflux), can lead to daytime and nighttime urinary incontinence due to reduced ability to concentrate the urine.  Patients often also have fatigue, poor growth, hypertension, and edema.  Urinalysis usually reveals proteinuria and/or hematuria, and serum creatinine is elevated.

Nonrenal/urologic causes

  • Type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM):  Nocturnal enuresis may be a presenting symptom of new-onset T1DM; patients also typically have polyuria, polydipsia, and weight loss.
  • Constipation:  Enuresis can occur with chronic constipation due to increased bladder pressure from a distended colon.  A history of infrequent stooling, straining with bowel movements, and passing hard stools is typical; palpation of stool on abdominal examination supports the diagnosis, and associated encopresis (fecal incontinence) is a sign of stool impaction.
  • Psychosocial stressors:  Behavioral regression, including enuresis, may be seen in the setting of psychosocial stressors (eg, new home, birth of a sibling, parental divorce).  This condition is also a diagnosis of exclusion, and a thorough social history often reveals a stressor.
  • Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA):  Nocturnal enuresis secondary to OSA should be considered in a child who has bed-wetting in addition to daytime sleepiness, behavioral concerns (eg, inattention, impulsivity), hypertension, and/or adenotonsillar hypertrophy.  Polysomnography confirms apneas and obstructive hypoventilation.
  • Arginine vasopressin disorders (diabetes insipidus):  Patient presentation is similar to T1DM, with polyuria, polydipsia, and enuresis.  However, urinalysis reveals a low specific gravity (rather than glucosuria) due to antidiuretic hormone resistance or deficiency.

Evaluation

Initial evaluation of a patient with bed-wetting involves a thorough history and physical examination plus urinalysis.

History and examination should focus on the timeline of bed-wetting (ie, primary vs secondary) as well as clinical features that may point to a specific cause (eg, poor growth in CKD, daytime sleepiness in OSA).  Patients with secondary enuresis or symptoms suggestive of an underlying medical condition should undergo detailed evaluation guided by these findings (eg, serum creatinine, polysomnography) (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
).

Because primary nocturnal enuresis may be present in a patient with a developing secondary condition, urinalysis should be performed in all children with nocturnal enuresis, regardless of associated symptoms, to assess for secondary medical causes:

  • Leukocyte esterase and/or nitrites may indicate an occult UTI.
  • Glycosuria is suggestive of T1DM.
  • Dilute urine (specific gravity <1.005) may suggest arginine vasopressin disorders.

Diagnosis

Primary nocturnal enuresis is a diagnosis of exclusion based on the following findings:

  • A history of bed-wetting without a prolonged period of nighttime dryness.
  • No additional urinary symptoms, systemic findings, or examination abnormalities suggestive of an underlying medical condition.
  • Normal urinalysis.

Prognosis and management

The natural course of primary nocturnal enuresis is spontaneous resolution, which may take months to years to achieve (eg, resolved in 93% of children by age 7 and 98% of children by age 12).  Males generally reach this milestone later than females, and the condition persists into adulthood for approximately 1% of patients.

Due to the high rate of spontaneous resolution, reassurance, follow-up, and treatment of any comorbid, potentially exacerbating conditions (eg, constipation) are appropriate.  However, many families seek active intervention to improve quality of life due to psychosocial stress or disrupted sleep.

Behavioral modifications

Initial steps in management include behavioral modifications (eg, minimizing evening fluid intake, voiding before bedtime) and motivational interventions (eg, sticker charts).  Patients are often instructed to keep a voiding diary to identify modifiable habits (eg, evening fluid intake).  Notably, having the parent periodically wake the child is not recommended because the child becomes reliant on the parent's intervention to void rather than on physiologic cues (eg, bladder fullness).

Enuresis alarm

For children who do not respond to lifestyle changes, enuresis alarm therapy is the most effective long-term intervention but can take 3-4 months to be effective.  An enuresis alarm is activated when a sensor in the patient's underwear or bed pad detects moisture and triggers an auditory or vibratory alarm that wakes the patient, thereby inhibiting further bladder emptying.  With consistent use, the enuresis alarm conditions the child to wake prior to voiding.  Patient adherence and motivation are required because the child is responsible for responding to the alarm.

Pharmacotherapy

Desmopressin, an antidiuretic hormone analogue, is an alternate first-line therapy recommended for families seeking a short-term solution (eg, for sleepaway camp) or for patients whose enuresis alarm therapy has failed or been refused.  However, the rate of relapse on discontinuation of desmopressin therapy is high.  Patients should be counseled on minimizing fluid intake in the evening to prevent hyponatremia with therapy.

Tricyclic antidepressants (eg, imipramine) are not first-line therapy for enuresis but can be considered for refractory cases.  Efficacy results from the anticholinergic effect of urinary retention.

Summary

Primary nocturnal enuresis (

) presents in children age â‰¥5 who have not achieved nighttime continence and is caused by maturational delay in bladder control.  This condition is a diagnosis of exclusion based on a thorough history and physical examination excluding underlying medication conditions (eg, urinary tract infection, type 1 diabetes mellitus), as well as a normal urinalysis.  The natural course of primary nocturnal enuresis is spontaneous resolution, but sleep disruption and/or psychosocial stress may warrant intervention (eg, enuresis alarm therapy).
